content.text: Consider the structure of the amino acid isoleucine. <image 1>  How many optical isomers does isoleucine have?

Isoleucine has two chiral centers, which means it can exist in four different stereoisomeric forms (two pairs of enantiomers). However, only one of these forms is found in nature and is used by living organisms. This form is known as L-isoleucine. The other three stereoisomers are not commonly found in nature and are not typically considered when discussing the optical isomers of isoleucine in a biological context.

Therefore, isoleucine has one naturally occurring optical isomer, L-isoleucine.

final_answer:
Isoleucine has two chiral centers, which means it can exist in four different stereoisomeric forms (two pairs of enantiomers). However, only one of these forms is found in nature and is used by living organisms. This form is known as L-isoleucine. The other three stereoisomers are not commonly found in nature and are not typically considered when discussing the optical isomers of isoleucine in a biological context.

Therefore, isoleucine has one naturally occurring optical isomer, L-isoleucine.
